1.words: All right. Welcome to the conversation at Cortico's Local Voices Network and United Way of Dane County. Thank you for agreeing to participate. I'm starting to record and to make sure we're all on the same page. I want to share the four main purposes for this conversation. First and foremost, we want to create a new space and a new way for members of our community to listen, to and learn about each other's lives. Second, we want to offer ways for members of our community to connect with and build relationships with one another. Third, we want to support LVNs new and unique technology that offers a different way to hear and lift up the voices and concerns of members of our community, like you, and share them with elected officials, local policy makers, and members of the media. And lastly, to support United Way's desire to learn directly from our community to inform their work, United Way requested this collaboration with LVN to ensure that your voices and perspectives are available to help inform their fun strategic agendas. Following your conversations today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will be transcribed and added to a collection of the United Way Centennial Conversations hosted on LVN website. The audio recording will be available to journalists, public officials, researchers, and other participants and partners in project at Cortico and United Ways discretion with the goal of eventually making them accessible to the public. As a participant in this conversation you are providing consent to Cortico the operator of the Local Voices Network and United Way Dane County to use the recording in accordance with the goal to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. This is a public conversation and portions of it may appear in the local newspaper or website or to be broadcast in the local radio station or appear elsewhere, other forms of media. So please share only what you're comfortable with being heard by the general public. And if you agree, or if you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

6.words: Okay. Sounds good. And I am just going to make a list in order of, oops, sorry. I didn't mean to press enter right away. Okay. Is everyone's name in the chat that I just sent? Okay. During our time together, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to both share and to learn from others in this conversation to support these goals. We have a few guidelines for our conversation. These are the same guidelines that were included in the materials we sent to confirm your participation in the meeting. One, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, allow others to speak for themselves, share the time, allow others to finish speaking and take turns, stay curious, ask honest questions. Pause. Take time for reflection. Listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact and when possible close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications, and put your phone on silent. Is everyone on board with these guidelines? Is there anything you would like to add or change? All right. And the names I just did are kind of like a modified circle so we can take turns and we'll just go by that order if that's okay with all of you. To do this, I will help transition us from one person to the next. You can always pass our pass and ask for us to come back to you. And if you have any questions about this process, please let me know. And to begin, I want to do just a quick round of introductions. So if Maggie, you would like to start?

7.words: Hi, I'm Maggie. I'm a junior here at UW. I'm studying environmental science and I'm from one of the many suburbs of Chicago.

8.words: Sorry, I forgot to mention, if you could also say your pronouns and a value that is important to you. Sorry, I should've mentioned this before.

9.words: It's okay. My pronouns are she, hers, and something I value is honesty.

10.words: And if Amelia, you wanted to go next?

11.words: Yeah. Hi, I'm Amelia. I'm a sophomore and I'm majoring in data science. I'm also from one of the suburbs of Chicago. My pronouns are she, her and I'd say a value is probably like listening to other people and being receptive to feedback, I guess.

12.words: Okay. And Megan, if you would want to go next.

13.words: Hey, I'm Meghan. I'm a junior here at UW. I'm from Rochester, Minnesota. I'm majoring in conservation bio and psych and she, her pronouns and I value loyalty.

14.words: Okay, nice. And Elizabeth, would you like to go?

15.words: Hi, my name's Elizabeth. I go by Libby. I'm a freshman here at UW studying English. My pronouns are she, her, hers and something that I value is kindness.

16.words: And would you like us to call you Libby on here or is Elizabeth okay?

20.words: I will also say mine just so you can get a chance to know who I am. My name is Justyce, I am a student at UW Madison, and I'm a senior and I'm a local voices network intern. My pronouns, are she, her, hers. And a value that is important to me is respect. I feel like we learned from a very young age that treat others the way you'd like to be treated. And so that is a big aspect. So moving on, the next thing I would like to do is invite you to share a little bit about your background, take a minute and think a personal story from your life that has shaped who you are. This story could be from your childhood, your adulthood, or work life, or maybe something you saw happen to someone else. And we can go backwards this time. So Elizabeth, if you would like to go first.

21.words: can I have another minute to think?

22.words: Yeah. Meghan, are you ready at all?

23.words: By life event, do you mean, a memory that we hold closely to ourselves or?

24.words: Yeah, I mean, that works too. Just something about your background. It doesn't have to be anything specific. And if it's a memory that works too.

25.words: Okay. I guess I'm interested in diversity equity inclusion because as a woman in STEM, it's like hard to be heard compared to other people. So I value intersectional environmentalism, and also like realize thing that like microaggressions are still prevalent in today's society.

26.words: All right, thank you. And Amelia, are you able to go?

27.words: Yeah. So I guess what I wanted to share was like, I'm adopted from China. So my parents are Caucasian, but then I'm Asian. So I think that had a big role but that was a big part of me growing up and kind of trying to, be comfortable with that. And it's, I guess it's kind of weird, I guess seeing my family in public, we don't all look the same, so that's kind of taught me just like, you more accepting of other people.

28.words: Yeah. I definitely know how you feel there. I, well, not the adoption part, but being mixed race and along those lines. And Maggie, would you like to go?

29.words: Yeah. I grew up Catholic, which I know being Christian is one of the major religions in our society, but the town that I grew up in was pretty Jewish. I don't know the exact like proportion, but I grew up going to, and having a lot of Jewish friends and getting to learn their culture both in like my Sunday school and also from their religious services, which I think has helped me view my religion in a different aspect, but also to be accepting of people of different religions. But it also has sheltered me a little bit. The people from my area, we always say we grew up in a bubble and then when we get to college, that bubble has popped and I'm still learning and continuing to learn from different people around me. So in some ways I was privileged, but I also got to see some diversity, just not as much as what other people might've grown up seeing.

30.words: All right. Thank you for sharing that. And we want to move on to the conversations about your hopes and concerns for the community. As you know, this conversation will be used to inform United Ways, future strategic initiatives. Before we move into the conversation, I would like to ask, what do you think United Way of Dane County does in our community? Oh! Sorry. I totally forgot to go back to Elizabeth for the background part. If you wanted to share again or share you can, if you don't want to it's okay.

31.words: It's all good. I was just going to say that I worked with a peer assistance and Leadership program when I was in high school and it was working with people with learning disabilities and things like that. And so, as far as that goes, there's like a lot that needs to be done there. But the community I definitely grew up in was not very diverse so it's still learning and it's really interesting to be here, worth so much.

32.words: All right. Thank you for sharing that and sorry for skipping over you. Now getting back to what you... or if you know anything about Dane County and if you don't, it's okay to say you don't. So we'll just go, we'll go in ups order again. So Maggie, would you like to go?

33.words: Yeah. I haven't heard of this program before, but so I don't know too much, but I hope that they're trying to... In our sorority, we've just recently created a diversity and equity inclusion chair. So I'm hoping that the live voices network, is that the name of the program again?

35.words: Local voices. Okay. That they're trying to do the same thing on maybe a little bit of a wider scale than just within a sorority chapter and more statewide.

36.words: Yeah. So The Local Voices Network is who I'm interning for, and they are partnering, with United Way of Dane County which is a nonprofit. And Amelia, would you like to go?

37.words: Yeah. I don't know too much about Dane County, honestly, because I haven't been in Madison for... or I just got, sorry. I just got in Madison last year from my freshman year, so I've only been here for like a little bit of time. But yeah, I guess I would hope like... I think small changes can be really effective and like gradually can get to a larger change. So I think just thinking about small things that you say and making people more aware of how that might affect others, connection with a bigger effect than a lot of people think.

38.words: Thank you for sharing. And Megan, would you like to go?

39.words: Yeah, I've never heard of the program that you were talking about before, but like you said, it's a nonprofit, so I would hope that they'd be doing a fundraising for like marginalized communities in Dane County and raising awareness for the community so that we can start having the discussions about like racing.

40.words: Yeah. Thank you for that. And Elizabeth, would you like to go?

41.words: So I moved to Madison recently and I'm not really aware of it, but I think it's always good to start conversations.

42.words: Yeah, I totally agree. Right. Thank you for that. Next I have got a few questions to start us off, but please know that we hope this will be a time for some back and forth among you, as you share your stories. All right. My next question is, what do you most appreciate about Dane County? And can you share an experience to explain that appreciation? And I know a lot of you have just experiences with UW Madison or just Madison, and that is fine too. With any experience you have, so Elizabeth, if you would like to go.

43.words: So this is about my experience in Madison?

44.words: So the question is, what do you most appreciate about Dane County? And you can share an experience to explain that appreciation if you would like.

45.words: Okay. I really love Madison as a city. It reminds me a lot of Austin. They both have like big schools and universities doing a lot for the community and like they're the capitals of their States. So there's also like the government aspect of that. And so when it mixes, it's really interesting. So it was just nice to have another place that felt kind of home, but just, further away with new people.

46.words: Yeah. Thank you for sharing that. And Megan, would you like to go?

47.words: Yeah, I think that the thing I appreciate the most about Dane County is that there's such a wide diversity in activities and things to do. It's so easy to make Madison, which is like 40,000 some people make it feel like a really tightened community, which I like, there's clubs for absolutely everybody and everybody's interest. And I like that there's the nature side of it and also like the city aspect. So you can do anything on any given day.

48.words: Yeah, I totally agree with that. Amelia, would you like to go?

49.words: Yeah. I really like Madison. I think it's a really nice city and it's way more diverse than the community that I grew up in. And I think the students, at least at this school are really proactive, and kind of stand for what they believe in which I like.

50.words: Yeah, for sure. And Maggie, would you like to go?

51.words: I agree with pretty much all you guys have said before, Madison is definitely a really interesting city, how it's both a college, town and the capital of the state it's in, but I spent most of this past summer up in Madison in my apartment. And one thing I didn't realize before when I was a freshmen and sophomore was how accessible Madison is. I really struggled with trying to figure out my grocery situation because there are a few like grocery stores on campus, but the better ones where I can get a little bit more food are further out. So I had to utilize the bike paths and I didn't realize how far they cross all over Dane County. So I would take bike rides just around just to see how else I can navigate. Plus the bus system, I think really helps with that too. Being able to explore outside of campus.

52.words: Yeah, I totally agree with that. When I got here, I'm a senior this year and I didn't know how to take the bus when I first got here, because back home I had never taken the bus. So I was overwhelmed because the buses go everywhere. And so I was a little lost at first, but I totally agree with how accessible Madison is. Could we just go around and say what year we are? I wanted to just get an idea of like how long you guys have been in Madison.

57.words: Okay. Thank you. I just kind of want to get an idea, sorry, if you already said that. And so moving on to the next question. As United Way begins to set priorities, they are interested in hearing what most concerns you about your life in Dane County at this time. And can you share a story that we'll talk more about this concern? And we also can like talk amongst ourselves. So if you have like a comment on somebody else's story or what they have to say, feel free to join in on the conversation. So Maggie, if you would like to go?

58.words: Yeah, I can't think of anything particularly off the top of my head, but I know that being a woman does put all of us at some sort of risk. I don't know but I think we might all be in our pledge classes have different group chats. And yesterday someone in mine had posted something about two guys wearing like MAGA hats and carrying assault weapons was walking around at night, around a university avenue. I didn't look at the photo, but I'm just saying like, be aware, be careful. And I was like, "Okay yeah, I'm not stepping outside of my apartment tonight." So, there is that concern of like my safety and the safety of other women and people of color around me, but I haven't experienced a ton of that, but I don't know if anybody else has and wants to share more about that.

59.words: Yeah. I was going to say similar things, just like safety in general, I guess, could be a concern and that's kind of expected just because it's a big city. And I know, especially out on state street at night, it can get dangerous. So yeah, I was pretty much going to say the same thing as you.

60.words: Yeah I totally agree there because being... I mixed with white and black and being colored in a time like this and also walking at night, I kind of get freaked out sometimes. And most times I like talk on the phone with somebody when I'm walking at night, just because I don't know, things can happen. And I never thought of this, I never wildly walked around too much. And when I was in high school, but being in Madison, I just feel like we... it's kind of sad that we have to look out for our surroundings at night or we can't walk outside at night because it's dangerous or in the early mornings or so I definitely hear you there. And let's see Meghan, do you have anything to add or something new about what you or your concerns are?

61.words: Yeah, I guess I'm just concerned that like Dane County is pretty undiverse as a college campus. I think UW is one of the least diverse colleges in the nation. So when I walk around campus or I go to classes, pre COVID I guess my concern is, that I kind of feel like I stand out, or being asked "Oh, no, where are you really from?". Things like that, microaggressions are just they're alive and well in Madison.

62.words: Yeah. I've definitely gotten asked that question too. And so it's definitely... I don't know. It's a shock to hear it, but... Amelia, would you, I already know you've kind of talked. Is there anything else you would like to mention at all?

63.words: Yeah. Going off of what Megan said there's definitely a bunch of comments I get, I don't think people mean for them to be offensive. They end up being offensive and especially in Greek life too. I get mistaken for a lot of other Asian people in my sorority or in other sororities. And it's like you just don't really see that happening. It's like other people, but for some reason, I don't know, people just do that.

65.words: I have had that happened to me too. Amelia.

66.words: Thank you for sharing that. It's definitely frustrating at some sometimes. And like you said, a lot of people don't mean it to be offensive, but and Maggie, did everyone share, sorry, I kinda lost track of the order.

68.words: Oh, I'm so sorry. I skipped.

69.words: It's all good. I definitely, I don't know, I was followed on state street once or twice and like big groups of people, so that wasn't great. Definitely safety as a concern.

70.words: Yeah. Thank you for sharing that. That is definitely scary. Yeah, I don't know what I would've done and that kind of situation. And now I would like to bring in the voices of someone who participated in a conversation in the Local Voices Network recently. I want you to imagine this, or imagine that this person is in a room with us and listened closely to their comments. I will then invite you to share any responses and insights you gained from listening to these comments. All right. I'm going to share, one second. Sorry. I'm having some difficulties because the highlights are not popping up, one second here. Sorry. I'm having difficulties. Okay. I'm going to play just a little bit and see if you can hear it. Could you hear that? Okay. I'm so sorry. I might have to share. Okay. Could you hear that?

71.words: Is there an option to like, share your sound? I think sometimes people have to do that.

72.words: Sharing the sound. Okay. Let me check. Unless I stopped sharing for a second. Okay. I don't know. Maybe it couldn't because I have Airpods. Yeah, let me try it one more time. Let me know if you guys can hear it.

74.words: Okay. Maybe if I put the link in the chat, you could go and possibly listen to it. Would that work for you guys? And it's not very long. Just a couple seconds or a minute or so max. Are you guys able to play it? Okay. I'll give you a couple... I'll let you listen to it.(silence). And just let me know when you watched it. Oh, yours done. Sorry. Okay. So let's pause to collect reflections. Would anyone like to share what insights, reactions or memories came to mind from listening to that audio clip? And I forgot which way we started for the last rotation, but Maggie, would you like to go at all?

75.words: Yeah. I've never been to the Twin City, so I can't speak from experience. So I'll take her word for how diverse it is. But the shock of hearing her say that the police officer was like, "You can either go that way, that way or in the car." And I was like, are you serious? I don't know. It was just really frustrated me that, that police officer didn't even try to help her at all.

76.words: Oops Sorry , I totally agree and thanks for sharing. And Amelia, would you like to go?

77.words: [Desconda], made me think of... I guess when I first came to Madison, I think there's just kind of a set. There's some things I know that are just not okay to say. And then I could think when it came to Madison, met a bunch of different people from different backgrounds, it's like, they would be okay with saying those things. I've just kind of always known just don't say it. I guess certain words, certain phrases like that. So I guess this kind of reminded me of that. I guess it made me think of that everyone, kind of depending on where you grew up and what your brain was like, have different offensive and what's wrong to say. So when I was hearing this story, I was like the police officer probably didn't even see anything wrong with what he was saying. And kind of didn't even realize how bad it... and how offensive it can be.

78.words: Yeah. I totally agree with that. And I've noticed that too on campus and you can definitely see, or you can definitely tell who grew up knowing what words to say were okay. And yeah. And Meghan, would you like to go at all?

79.words: Yeah. I was sadly not surprised by the video, just because Madison is like this bubble that we're talking about because we're so, our campus is so diverse and that kind of just shows in our language, like Amelia was saying were so much less sensitive to other people's backgrounds and what they might be going through, just because we're so limited in our perspective. And also, even if a police officer did realize that it was offensive, I'm not surprised that he didn't say anything, especially when you're comparing it to the Minnesota Police Department with everything that's happened this past year.

80.words: Yeah, sure. Thanks for sharing and Elizabeth would you like to go?

81.words: Yeah, I just thought the whole thing was sad. I don't know. I can't say that I relate to it. But I don't think anyone should have to, so...

82.words: Yeah. Thanks for sharing. And here's another question for a little more reflection, given our conversation what is one change you would most like to see happen? And also what person, group, or organization do you think would be best equipped to make the changes you would like most to see happen? So if we could go backwards in the line, Elizabeth, if you would like to go first.

83.words: Yeah, I was just, love to see everyone be more inclusive. And I don't know if there's really an organization that can do that. I kind of think it just starts with the people.

84.words: Yeah, for sure. Thank you for sharing that. Meghan, would you like to go?

85.words: Yeah, I completely agree with what Libby had to say, because if that curiosity or that sense of responsibility that you need to be educated and to help educate and have those hard conversations with your friends and family, then it's not going to happen because an institution is telling you to do that. So I don't think it's up to one organization, but it would be nice if it was that simple.

86.words: Yeah. I totally agree. Amelia, would you like to go?

87.words: I think a change I'd want to see is for people to be more, I guess listen to other people, listen to how your words make them feel. Because obviously people might slip up and say something that is offensive. And I think the most important thing, like that situation is to listen to what the other person is saying and just be receptive to it and not do it again. I think some people when they get that type of reaction, they get defensive about it and don't want to change or admit they're wrong. So I think a change I'd like to see is just being open to changing some of your views as you learn more.

88.words: Yeah. I totally agree with that.

91.words: No, I'm sorry. I didn't. Okay. Yeah. I agree with you Amelia. I think as a whole, we need to be better active listeners, both listening to what other people are saying, but also thinking about what we're going to say before we say it, because I do think as a white person, I need to learn from the experiences of other people of color and of other diversities. And I shouldn't be one to proclaim things I don't feel that's really my place. But I do need to be paying actively attention to what these people are saying so that I can make changes in my perspectives and start to think differently and more inclusively towards other people. And I don't know. I have heard of the Multicultural student center on campus. I was involved with like the ASM sustainability committee last year and we were trying to work on social sustainability, making it accessible to anybody. Because I feel like our picture of sustainability is kind of in the, what we think of sustainability is like typically like buying reusable straws, buying this, buying that, and that's kind of not accessible for everybody. So we were trying to do work with the Multicultural students center and they seemed really interested in what we were doing too. So I feel like they would be one of the bigger organizations on campus that could try to provide that change.

92.words: Thank you for sharing that. And I appreciate you wanting to learn more about that. It's really cool. To go along with what you guys were saying with all, just kinda hearing people a big thing and I'm like that I hope is that we can hear both sides of people's conversation and rather than fight, we can just kinda understand that people are going to think differently, but also be able to respectfully understand and not bash anyone for thinking different is what kind of I would like to see to go on with the conversation. So thank you for sharing your ideas about making Dane County more accessible for community members. And for my last question, we invite you to share one thing you heard today that you'll be taking away from this conversation and that you would like other people to hear. So Maggie, if you would like to go.

93.words: I may need a minute so if you want to come back to me.

94.words: Okay. I mean, we don't have to go in order. If anyone has their idea or thoughts, just there'll be ready to just say it.

95.words: Something that I'll take away from this is that, it's really easy for me to feel angry when I'm having these types of conversations, because I feel so passionately about them. And I have such a strong opinion that I can see myself being able to discard a person's opinion because it's opposite to mine when really I should be able to listen and learn from their perspective in order to question it or ask, why do you think that? And that can help my perspective also. So I think that being able to just see all different sides of any argument is a big takeaway for me.

96.words: I think that I've learned that I just need to be more observant of the things going on around me then just more inclusive to everyone and definitely just more aware.

97.words: I think what I took away is I should have more conversations like this. I feel like I guess I read a lot or watch videos, but it really helps to talk to other people and just kind of say what you're thinking. Because I think being educated in this aspect is like, this is not kind of a one and done thing. It's kind of you're always growing and always learning more things.

98.words: Yeah. I do agree that like learning is not linear. It doesn't end with like completing your ethnic studies course or whatever, but I think I've taken away that it doesn't just stop after I complete that course it continues and it's something I'm gonna continue to learn throughout my life as I encounter different experiences. But [inaudible] so harsh on myself for not... Sometimes I get mad at myself, well, why didn't I know that? And it's like, I didn't know that because I grew up in an area that didn't have that experience for me. So just learning to be more gentle on people who are not gentle, but being able to forgive them if they said something that was maybe not correct in some way. And if they didn't have a mean intention just to put some perspective, like they're trying to learn and we can help educate one another.

99.words: Yeah. Thank you for sharing your thoughts. Those were all great takeaways. So those are all the prepared questions that I have for you. Do you have any closing thoughts you'd like to share other general reflections on the conversation at all?[crosstalk 00:46:05].

100.words: Sorry. You said at the beginning they might use some of the stuff we said in articles or newspapers or something. Would you like let us know, what we know of about that if it happened?

101.words: Yeah, for sure. So nothing is published yet. So what happens is like Anna said the video recording will be trashed and then it's just the audio recording and then we, so what mine and Anna's job, we go through these conversations and kind of listen to everything we shared and pick out different highlights. Like she said, this is all going to end in a report and I'm not totally sure what happens with that report. I know it goes to United Way. So they can figure out different events or to help with these issues that were addressed. But I'm sure if anything ended up in a newspaper or a different article, I'm sure they most likely contact you and I'm not totally sure about the answer, but that's what I can give and I can totally contact my higher up too, if you really want to know that and I can let Anna know and she can let you know if that's what you want.

103.words: Okay. Yeah. I don't know anything about it being put in a newspaper article or, but yeah, sorry that wasn't a very good answer, but...

105.words: And does anyone else have any other questions? All right. And just a reminder of what will happen with the thoughts you just shared. These recordings will be transcribed, indexed and shared on The Local Voices Network Website, where they can be assessed by journalists, public officials, participants in Local Voices Network and United Way's Centennial project. We encourage you to spread the word about Local Voices Network and opportunities to support United Way's work. And also going back to your thought Amelia. So once we go through the conversations and our whole audio recording will be posted on the Local Voices Network and made public. So if you did want to listen to this conversation back, you definitely could go there and look for the conversation. And if you want to convene another group of friends to participate or know of others who would want to participate, please go to lvn.org or reach out to us via the contact info shared. Thank you so much for joining us and sharing your thoughts to help inform United way of Dane county's future strategic agendas. And I'm going to just stop recording.
